activities.title: Foundation: Why Are Questions So Important?
activities.body: Sawaal hi aapka sabse powerful tool hai for learning, clarifying, or making friends. Aap jitne achche se poochoge, utni jaldi aapki English improve hogi!

activities.caption: Master the rules, and you’ll never be stuck again!

activities.title: Building Question Sentences: Detailed Rules (Part 1)
activities.body:
1) **Identify the Info**: Pata karo aapko detail chahiye (WH) ya sirf yes/no?

2) **Pick Your ‘Helper Word’** (auxiliary): do/does/did, is/are/am, can/could, will/would, etc.

3) **Decide the Word Order**:
   - For yes/no: [Aux] + [Subject] + [Verb] + (Object/extra)?
     e.g., ‘Do you speak English?’
   - For WH: [WH word] + [Aux] + [Subject] + [Verb]?
     e.g., ‘Where do you live?’

4) **Politeness** (if needed): add “Could you...?”, “Would you mind...?” or “May I...?”

activities.text: Badi simple baat: English question = “Inversion” (aux before subject) + optional WH word. Bas yahi rule yaad rakho!

activities.caption: This image helps visualize how we invert words to form questions.

activities.title: Building Question Sentences: Detailed Rules (Part 2)
activities.body:
5) **Extra Words**: If a question needs a direct object or adverb, place it after the verb. E.g., “What do you like to eat for breakfast?”

6) **Subject vs. Object Questions**: ‘Who ate the cake?’ (no auxiliary needed if “who” is the subject). But ‘Who did you meet?’ (aux needed if “who” is object). Trickier but helps advanced.

7) **Tag Questions**: Add ‘..., isn’t it?’ or ‘..., do you?’ at the end for confirmation.

8) **Practice**: The more you try building questions from these rules, the more natural it becomes!

activities.text: Role-play: Construct a question from scratch. Example: You want to know if your friend likes coffee. Step 1) yes/no => use do. Step 2) Invert => Do + subject (you) + verb (like) => ‘Do you like coffee?’
Story #1: Ek banda bola, ‘Where do me live you?’ Samne wala confused! Let’s do it right: ‘Where do you live?’
Lesson: Grammar mistake se bacha ja sakta hai, agar aap basic structure yaad rakho!

activities.title: Basic ‘Wh’ Questions
activities.body:
• What’s your name?
• Where do you live?
• When does this shop open?
• Who is your favorite singer?
• Why are you studying English?
• How can I get there?

In sab se aap conversation start ya continue kar sakte ho!

activities.prompt: Try saying: ‘What’s your name? Where are you from?’ in a friendly tone!

activities.text: Role-play: You meet a new person at a cafe. Ask them 2 ‘Wh’ questions to break the ice!

activities.title: Choosing WH vs. Yes/No
activities.body:
If you want a short ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ answer => Start with do/does/is/are/can. But if you want details => Start with wh-word + [aux].

For example:
• *Yes/No*: ‘Do you speak English?’ => answer: ‘Yes, I do!’
• *WH*: ‘How many languages do you speak?’ => answer: ‘I speak 3...’

activities.title: Yes/No Questions—Simple But Powerful
activities.body:
• Do you like coffee?
• Can you help me?
• Are you busy?
• Is it raining?

In sab se short, direct answers milte hain!

activities.question: Which is a proper yes/no question?
hints: Yes/No questions often start with do/does/am/is/are/can, etc.

activities.title: Polite Question Starters
activities.body:
• ‘Could you please...?’
• ‘Would you mind...?’
• ‘May I ask...?’

Yeh phrases se aap formality & respect dikha sakte ho!

activities.question: Which is more polite?
options: Could you please give me your phone number?
Tell me your phone number... maybe?
activities.encouragementOnFail: Try again—look for a phrase that shows courtesy!

activities.text: Yes, “Could you please...” is instantly more polite than commanding!
Role-play: Aap ek new colleague se unka email address poochna chahte ho. Use a polite question starter!

activities.title: 💡 Tag Questions
activities.body:
‘It’s sunny today, isn’t it?’
‘You can join us, can’t you?’

Tag questions make conversation friendly & keep the flow going!

activities.prompt: Try saying: ‘You like music, don’t you?’ with a light, friendly tone!

activities.question: Which tag question is correct?
options: They can help, can they help?
We speak English, do we speak it?
hints: Tag questions usually invert the verb & pronoun: ‘..., isn’t she?’ ‘..., didn’t they?’

activities.text: Story #2: ‘You love cricket, do you do you?’—Double question? Samne wala soch raha, ‘Huh?!’
Moral: Tag questions are short—‘..., do you?’ or ‘..., isn’t it?’—Don’t repeat it!

activities.prompt: Say: ‘This coffee is delicious, isn’t it?’

activities.caption: Asking everyday questions with friends—makes life simpler!

activities.title: Advanced Tip: Questions for Clarification
activities.body:
When you don’t understand, use phrases:
• ‘Pardon? Could you repeat that?’
• ‘Sorry, what do you mean by that?’
• ‘I’m not sure I follow—could you clarify?’

Confidence boost: Don’t be afraid to ask again!

activities.question: If you don’t understand something, do you usually ask again?

activities.text: English seeks clarity, so never hesitate to politely re-ask your question!
Practice these question forms daily—zaroori hai to get comfortable in real conversations!

activities.question: Which question politely asks for repetition?
options: Could you say that once more, please?
I not hear, sorry. Talk again?
hints: Look for a ‘Could you... please?’ structure

activities.text: Good job! ‘Could you say that once more, please?’ is polite & clear.

activities.title: ❗ Common Pitfalls
activities.body:
• Mixing question word order: ‘Where you live do?’
• Forgetting to be polite: ‘Give me info!’
• Over-apologizing: ‘I sorry, I no speak well—listen me?’

Confidence > Apologies!

activities.title: Comprehensive List: Real-Life Questions (Part 1)
activities.body:
**A) Introductions / Basic Info**
1) What’s your name?
2) Where are you from?
3) Which city do you live in?
4) How old are you? (Use carefully—some find it personal)
5) What do you do for a living?

**B) Daily Life**
1) Do you have time to talk?
2) Are you free later?
3) When do you usually wake up?
4) Can you help me carry this?
5) Where can I find a good restaurant nearby?

**C) Friends / Social**
1) Who’s your favorite actor?
2) What kind of music do you like?
3) Do you watch [sport/TV show]?
4) Could you recommend me something fun to do?
5) Are you on social media? (Polite: ‘May I add you?’)

activities.caption: A portion of real-life Q’s—so you never run out of ways to ask!

activities.title: Comprehensive List: Real-Life Questions (Part 2)
activities.body:
**D) Travel / Directions**
1) Where is the bus stop?
2) When is the next train?
3) How long does it take to get there?
4) Do I need to buy a ticket first?
5) Could you show me the way on the map?

**E) Work / Office**
1) Could you send me that file?
2) When is the deadline?
3) Do you have a moment to discuss this?
4) Who should I report to?
5) May I schedule a meeting?

**F) Services / Customer Support**
1) Do you have [item/service] in stock?
2) Could you please fix/replace this?
3) How long does the process take?
4) Is there any additional fee?
5) May I speak to a manager (if it’s serious)?

activities.caption: We’re still adding more so you never feel stuck!

activities.title: Comprehensive List: Real-Life Questions (Part 3)
activities.body:
**G) Restaurant / Food**
1) Do you have vegetarian options?
2) May I see the menu?
3) What do you recommend?
4) Could I have some water, please?
5) Is there any spice level choice?

**H) Health / Medical**
1) Can I book an appointment?
2) What time does the clinic open?
3) Do I need a prescription?
4) How do I take this medicine?
5) Could you explain the side effects?

**I) Formal Polite**
1) Would you mind helping me with this task?
2) Could I ask you a question about [topic]?
3) May I interrupt for a moment?
4) Might I get your opinion on this?
5) Is it okay if I call you later?

activities.caption: Endless possibilities—these question sets cover 90% of real scenarios!

activities.title: Comprehensive List: Real-Life Questions (Part 4) - The Finale!
activities.body:
**J) Phone Calls**
1) May I speak to [Name]?
2) Could you repeat the number/email?
3) Do you have a moment to talk?
4) Is this a good time, or should I call back?
5) Would you mind sending me a text?

**K) Confidence-Boosting**
1) Did I frame that question okay?
2) Could you correct me if I make mistakes?
3) Is my English understandable?
4) Are you comfortable with me asking?
5) May I practice more questions with you?

**These** will keep you prepared for nearly **any** everyday conversation scenario!
